title: Wednesday, 8th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE11:01am

Hey, hello, good morning, welcome, hi.

BE11:02am

And good news! I'm not solo today.

BE11:02am

Because joining me is Neil Hume.

11:02 am
NH11:02am

Hola

BE11:02am

Neil's FT's commodities editor these days. Though you'll probably know him better as founding member of the AV team and the editor for two years through the sov debt crisis.

NH11:02am

Mining and Commodities - they gave me more work to do

11:02 am
BE11:03am

Yes, that. And, unusually, it appears the system works. Good to have you with us Neil.

NH11:03am

It's been a while

NH11:03am

I think I remember how everything works

11:03 am
NH11:03am

DeadcatBuyBear

BE11:03am

The tradition these days is to start with a picture .....

NH11:03am

emoticons still there

11:03 am
NH11:03am

and bandits!

NH11:03am

Bandit1

NH11:04am

What's today's snapshot?

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Yeah, the bandits have fallen out of use of late, in part because I can't be bothered with 200 calls from "Hi, this is Steve at Parasite Capital can you spare some time to share some edge" ....

NH11:05am

Secretary of State for International Development ?

NH11:05am

Or the bloke who runs Snap?

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Is Priti still in the air, or has she been shot down yet?

NH11:06am

(Boncoeur - careful. I haven't forgotten how to zap)

NH11:06am

still in the air, I believe

11:05 am
NH11:06am

over Uganda

BE11:06am

Hm. Censored

BE11:06am

Anyway, I totally forgot to sort out a picture. You'll have to imagine something. And we can push on to the disaster that is Snap later.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

For the moment, we should take the briefest of looks at the FTSE. It's flat.

NH11:07am

Exciting

BE11:07am

7515, having dropped sharply late yesterday on a slightly inexplicable sterling bounce.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

Today we have, rather conveniently, some strength among the miners on the back of China figures.

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,456, no change, High: 1,466, Low: 1,452, Volume: 1.44m
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,751, up 17.5 (+0.47%), High: 3,771, Low: 3,738, Volume: 686.66k
11:08 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,489, down 0.5 (-0.03%), High: 1,502, Low: 1,484, Volume: 736.64k
NH11:08am

All a bit strange that

NH11:08am

Chinese preliminary trade figures for October look very weak at first glance

11:08 am
NH11:09am

iron ore imports dropped to 936mtpa (from 1,251mtpa in September

NH11:09am

that's an annualised number BTW

NH11:09am

coal imports (there is no split between met and thermal in the preliminary data) dropped to 250mtpa, the lowest since July. Copper unwrought imports also dropped to 330kt

11:09 am
NH11:09am

so not a sparkling set of numbers

BE11:09am

So, seasonal slowdown or something more significant?

NH11:09am

that said

11:09 am
NH11:09am

we did have the Golden Week effect in China

NH11:09am

plus the run up to the party congress

NH11:10am

so that will have hit the numbers

11:09 am
NH11:10am

plus usual season weakness

NH11:10am

and of course the China bears have leapt on this

NH11:10am

can I offer a bit of grey?

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Please.

NH11:10am

Via Capital Economics

NH11:10am

China’s commodity import volumes plummeted in October. While a shift in the timing of the MidAutumn Festival explains much of the decline, we think that there are now clear signs that domestic demand is cooling

11:10 am
NH11:10am

Growth in China’s total import bill eased back to 15.9% y/y in renminbi terms, down from 19.5% y/y in September. (For more, see the China Data Response sent this morning to clients of our China service.) We estimate that import volumes still rose by 8.8% y/y, but commodity imports were particularly weak. • Imports of the key industrial commodities all fell sharply m/m (see Chart 1), although oil, copper and soybeans imports were still up in year-on-year terms.

NH11:11am

Indeed, the bigger picture is that unwrought copper imports have revived over the course of this year. (See Chart 2.) That said, growth in copper ore imports has slowed, which may reflect the likelihood of lower refinery activity during the winter months. • Elsewhere, iron ore imports fell by nearly 25% m/m, but this was from a record high of 102.8m tonnes in September. The drop in imports is consistent with slower growth in steel output. (See Chart 3.) If the government-mandated shutdowns during the winter go ahead as planned, iron ore imports could fall further. That said, imported iron ore is typically higher quality and less polluting, which add to its appeal. • China’s commodity exports also continued to soften last month

NH11:11am

Steel exports have now fallen by a third this year owing to high domestic prices (making China’s exports less competitive), solid local demand and, in some cases, rising international protectionism. • To wrap up, the week-long Mid-Autumn Festival and Party Congress may have dampened trade and activity in October and imports may revive in November. However, the pollution crackdown and lower fiscal spending suggest that volumes will remain relatively low in the coming months.

11:11 am
NH11:11am

I don't the capacity cuts have really started to come through yet, but they will

BE11:11am

Apologies for my ignorance, though the regular readers should be used to it by now. What's Golden Week?

NH11:11am

Public Holiday in China

11:11 am
NH11:12am

which is well observed

NH11:12am

basically trading grounds to halt on SHFE and other China metals markets

NH11:12am

also on the China numbers we should just touch on oil

11:12 am
NH11:12am

Via Petromatrix

NH11:12am

China’s crude oil imports dropped to 7.34 myn b/d in October, the lowest level of the year, -1.7 myn b/d less than in September but +530 kb/d more than a year ago. For the year-to-date, imports average +910 kb/d more than a year ago.
China has however increased the quotas for independent refiners for 2018 by +1.0 myn b/d to 2.86 myn b/d (the quotas for independent refiners were cut in 2017).

NH11:13am

Brent and WTI a tad weaker this morning

11:13 am
NH11:13am

but both have had a good run

NH11:13am

Brent $63.60

BE11:13am

Since we're wandering subjects, ROTR mention Aramco ............

11:13 am
BE11:14am

What's the latest thinking? Is it going to the US?

NH11:14am

I'd be surprised

NH11:14am

too much litigation risk

11:14 am
NH11:14am

London looks better from that perspective

NH11:14am

personally I think they will list domestically next year

NH11:14am

bring in a Chinese investor

11:14 am
NH11:14am

and do the international listing further down the line

NH11:15am

probably London as well as Hong Kong

NH11:15am

(yes Boncoeur, plus reserve reporting)

11:15 am
NH11:16am

I think we can say the Crown Price is determined the reform the country

NH11:16am

whether it works is another thing

NH11:16am

but he's going to try

11:16 am
NH11:16am

Personally I find the Crown Prince's stance toward Iran the most interesting thing for the oil market

NH11:17am

a lot of tension

NH11:17am

although I can't see it impacting the Opec production deal

11:17 am
NH11:17am

because Iran's production is stuck at 3.7-3.8m b/d

NH11:17am

for all the talk of going to 4m b/d plus

NH11:17am

they can't get there

11:17 am
NH11:17am

So I don't think the deal falls apart when Opec meets later this month

NH11:17am

and that's good for oil

NH11:18am

Bryce, I have a quick comment on US shale if you'd like it

11:17 am
NH11:18am

from Opec

NH11:18am

and its latest World Energy Review

BE11:18am

Please.

11:18 am
NH11:18am

In its latest annual World Oil Outlook, OPEC sees US shale oil production rising by +600 kb/d in 2018 versus 2017, whereas a year ago they saw an increase of only +100 kb/d for 2018 vs 2107. Their base 2017 shale oil production level is also +1.0 myn b/d higher than expected a year ago and that makes their 2018 shale oil outlook +1.5 myn b/d higher than what they had a year ago. By 2019 they expect US shale oil production to be +2.1 myn b/d higher than they expected a year ago. The revisions are very large and illustrate once again the difficultly that oil economists have in making forecasts for US crude oil production growth.
The US EIA has increased is outlook for US production growth in 2018 to +720 kb/d (previous estimate at +680 kb/d). This compares to an expected growth of +370 kb/d in 2017. If Saudi Arabia maintains its supply cuts, then by the end of 2018 the US will be producing more crude oil than Saudi Arabia.

NH11:19am

That's again via Petromatrix - a v good Swiss oil consultant

BE11:19am

Thumbs up

11:19 am
undefined
NH11:20am

Shall we move on from commods?

BE11:20am

Yep. Snap headlines crossing in recent minutes.

11:20 am
NH11:20am

Snap?

NH11:20am

Tencent buying 145.87m non-voting shares in Snap / 10% of the company

BE11:20am

CNBC had the scoop that was, I make it, 30 seconds before the company statement.

11:21 am
NH11:21am

So one of those poo scoops

NH11:21am

where a reporter breaks the story two mins before its hits the tape

BE11:21am

We -- as in the FT -- were trying to stand this one up as well, but sourcing rules meant we couldn't say anthing.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Anyway, this is post dreadful Snap numbers overnight.

NH11:22am

Yeah, they were bad

BE11:22am

Revenue $207.9m vs $235.5m consensus.

11:22 am
NH11:23am

(fjp73 - ever considered a career as the head of major global trading company?)

BE11:23am

$178.9m loss and 2m active users in North America.

NH11:24am

I have the Snap filing re Tencent if we want it

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Forecasts for the active user figure (yes, people are forecasting active users again, like we learned nothing from 1999) were up around the 3.2 mark.

BE11:24am

Yep, please.

NH11:24am

one sec

11:24 am
NH11:24am

getting from my reuters screen

BE11:25am

(@Tom: ?)

NH11:25am

Because our Class A common stock is non-voting, significant holders of our common stock are exempt from the obligation to file reports under Sections 13(d), 13(g),
and 16 of the Exchange Act. These provisions generally require periodic reporting of beneficial ownership by significant stockholders, including changes in that ownership.
For example, in November 2017, Tencent Holdings Limited notified us that it, together with its affiliates, acquired 145,778,246 shares of our non-voting Class A common stock
via open market purchases. As a result of our ownership structure, Tencent and Snap are not obligated to disclose changes in Tencent’s ownership of our Class A common
stock, so there can be no assurance that you, or we, will be notified of any such changes. Our directors and officers are required to file reports under Section 16 of the
Exchange Act. Our significant stockholders, other than directors and officers, are exempt from the “short-swing” profit recovery provisions of Section 16 of the Exchange Act
and related rules with respect to their purchases and sales of our securities. As such, stockholders will be unable to bring derivative claims for disgorgement of profits for
trades by significant stockholders under Section 16(b) of the Exchange Act unless the significant stockholders are also directors or officers.

11:25 am
NH11:26am

Since our Class A common stock is our only class of stock registered under Section 12 of the Exchange Act and that class is non-voting, we are not required to file
proxy statements or information statements under Section 14 of the Exchange Act, unless a vote of the Class A common stock is required by applicable law. Accordingly, legal
causes of action and remedies under Section 14 of the Exchange Act for inadequate or misleading information in proxy statements may not be available to holders of our Class
A common stock. If we do not deliver any proxy statements, information statements, annual reports, and other information and reports to the holders of our Class B common
stock and Class C common stock, then we will similarly not provide any of this information to holders of our Class A common stock. Because we are not required to file proxy
statements or information statements under Section 14 of the Exchange Act, any proxy statement, information statement, or notice of our annual meeting may not include all
information under Section 14 of the Exchange Act that a public company with voting securities registered under Section 12 of the Exchange Act would be required to provide
to its stockholders. Most of that information, however, will be reported in other public filings. For example, disclosures required by

BE11:26am

Coo, that's a long filing.

NH11:27am

there's a bit more

11:26 am
NH11:27am

that seems to be a bit gushing

NH11:27am

mutual love in

NH11:27am

Our long-term shareholder Tencent Holdings Limited (“Tencent”), a global Internet company based in Shenzhen, China, has notified us that it has recently acquired
145,778,246 shares of our non-voting Class A common stock via open market purchases.
We have long been inspired by the creativity and entrepreneurial spirit of Tencent and we are grateful to continue our longstanding and productive relationship that
began over four years ago. For its part, Martin Lau, Tencent's President, informed us that Tencent is excited to deepen its shareholding relationship with us, and that it looks
forward to sharing ideas and experiences.

11:27 am
NH11:27am

I wonder if he has some ideas about design

BE11:28am

That'd be useful. As to the numbers last night, was interested to see references to "friction" for the Android app.

BE11:28am

In the sense that it just stopped bloody working. As I think I mentioned on here a while back.

11:28 am
NH11:29am

I've only seen it on an iphone

BE11:29am

Let me cut to UBS, who have a (now probably directionally wrong) sell downgrade out.

BE11:29am

In the first two quarters as a public company, we framed SNAP's disappointing results
as "growing pains" but felt the long-term debates around user growth and ad business
scaling were left unsolved. While many of those questions remain unanswered after a
third earnings report, it is now very likely that SNAP will continue to struggle on
multiple fronts in the coming 12 months - a redesigned app could bring opportunity
but also platform disruption & trying to scale its ad business as user growth is tepid
while competing against GOOG, FB & AMZN is likely going to prove difficult. We no
longer believe SNAP warrants a set of valuation metrics much different than its peers as
the company's growth prospects (while not producing anywhere near industry leading
profit metrics) decelerate in coming quarters.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Negatives in the qtr: a) Q3 global DAU net adds below UBS & Street ests (+4.5m vs.
Street at +8m QoQ); b) Lower than expected ad rev growth driven by continued pricing
pressure (CPMs down 60%YoY) due to shift towards programmatic (self-serve + API);
c) mgmt commentary that app redesign is likely to be disruptive to the business
(although timing remains unclear); and d) Spectacles inventory write-off. Positives in the
qtr: a) continued momentum in user engagement (growth in time spent, video views &
frequency of use in Q3; # of Snaps up 40%YoY); b) better than expected Adj.EBITDA
driven by greater cost discipline and mgmt comment about increased employee
productivity & slower headcount growth allowing for increased operating leverage.

BE11:30am

Our $7 PT is based on an equal blend of 8x EV/'18 Sales multiple (from 12x) & 30x
EV/'21(FCF-SBC) multiple (from 26x) discounted back 3yrs (discount rate unchanged).
Our lowered multiples reflect more muted forward revs and FCF expectations.

NH11:30am

We should probably reflect on the comments of the CEO

11:30 am
NH11:30am

on design etc

BE11:30am

Go on, remind me.

NH11:30am

The Los Angeles-based company was in the process of redesigning its app to improve usability, especially for Android devices, he said, as Snap tries to broaden its appeal beyond western millennials to older people and those in emerging markets. 

Mr Spiegel acknowledged the careful balancing act that Snapchat faces, in retaining the intimacy and fun that made it so appealing to young users. 

“There is a strong likelihood that the redesign of our application will be disruptive to our business in the short term, and we don’t yet know how the behaviour of our community will change when they begin to use our updated application,” he said. 

11:30 am
NH11:30am

That's from Tim Bradshaw's piece

NH11:31am

https://www.ft.com...-a1d2-6786f39ef675

NH11:31am

I'd liked this line

11:31 am
NH11:31am

Please use the sharing tools found via the email icon at the top of articles. Copying articles to share with others is a breach of FT.com T&Cs and Copyright Policy. Email licensing@ft.com to buy additional rights. Subscribers may share up to 10 or 20 articles per month using the gift article service. More information can be found at https://www.ft.com/tour.
https://www.ft.com...-a1d2-6786f39ef675

He pointed to the fact that Snapchat’s much-copied Stories format had “basically no one using it for the first six months or so”, as an example of how product development by “thesis”, rather than hard data, can prove successful. “I guess we are just not afraid to make changes in the long term interest of the business,” Mr Spiegel added. 

NH11:31am

development by thesis

NH11:31am

must remember that one

11:31 am
NH11:31am

sounds like development by pure guess work

NH11:32am

but what do I know I don't work in the Valley

BE11:32am

Is this like the Apple thing of not doing focus groups, because people don't know what they want until you tell them, except with a few academic words chucked in to impart a sense of intellectual rigour?

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Sounds like bobbins.

BE11:33am

Anyway, that's enough Snap.

undefined
11:33 am
BE11:33am

In terms of UK numbers we have Sophos.

Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 643.58, up 29.08 (+4.73%), High: 654.00, Low: 625.00, Volume: 1.11m
BE11:34am

Big jump in billings, perhaps thanks to the various ransomware and data loss stories we've had over the quarter.

11:34 am
NH11:34am

interesting

BE11:34am

Renewals and new customer numbers both going the right way.

NH11:35am

biggest gainer in the FTSE 250

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Billings and cash EBITDA (which is Sophos's own metric, as we've noted several times) both beat.

NH11:35am

Biggest riser in the FTSE 250 at the moment

BE11:36am

Up 22.1% and 30.8% respectively, which is hard to argue with. And there's cash at the bottom as well, unlike some other software companies we could mention.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Unlevered free cash up 14.8% to $71.4m.

BE11:37am

Guidance goes from 20% billings growth to 20-22%

NH11:37am

(Milky, Taxloss, Monkey. Where have they all gone?)

11:01 am
BE11:01am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the typing and etc.

BE11:37am

On reiterated 50-100bp improvement in cash EBITDA margins.

BE11:38am

(Milky still comes back sometimes. Taxloss is in a different timezone and Monkey has gone to a better place.)

11:38 am
NH11:38am

Do we have some grey?

BE11:38am

We do! Because everything's moving in the right direction, Numis has downgraded.

BE11:39am

Valuation argument.

11:39 am
NH11:39am

Right.

BE11:39am

(This is David Toms, who's excellent.)

BE11:39am

Sophos's Q2 has shown very strong growth, as we expected with our top-of-the-range forecasts. 28% billings growth (NSe 31%) to $177m (NSe $181m) with Cash EBITDA $39m (NSe $41m), 56% growth. FY guidance is raised to 20-22% billings growth (NSe 22% already) thus whilst we expect a c.3-5% increase in consensus, our forecasts remain unchanged at this stage. The standout figure is renewal rate, at 139% by value - given that renewals represent c.60% of billings, a strong renewal rate performance is highly beneficial for overall billings. Importantly, we still see potential for further strong performance from Sophos this year, with strong business momentum as Sophos Central eases the cross/upsell process, and InterceptX provides a highly attractive product for new and existing customers, at a time when well-publicised threats drive demand for such enhanced protection. TP moves up to 570p due to US$ movement.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

....

BE11:40am

Sustainability remains the key question. Sophos is benefiting from renewal rates well above historic norms, aided in our view by increasing Central penetration and InterceptX sales. Cybersecurity is such that there are always new threats, thus if Sophos can maintain sufficient product innovation, there will be further new products
to sell. Our forecasts assume that renewal rate and growth fades from 2018 onwards - if we are over-cautious on this, there could be good sustained upside. Conversely, the key risk we see is missing out on a future product cycle transition.

BE11:40am

That's the gist of it.

11:40 am
undefined
NH11:40am

OK. It's good we have brought up Sophos and IT security because I have a bit of RAW related to the sector

BE11:40am

Thumbs up

11:40 am
NH11:41am

Palo Alto Networks

NH11:41am

lots of interest in the stock

NH11:41am

$13bn market cap

11:41 am
NH11:41am

so quite chunky

NH11:41am

idea seems to be that it's on the radar screen of someone

NH11:41am

Palo Alto Networks is the next-generation security company maintaining trust in the digital age by helping tens of thousands of organizations worldwide prevent cyber breaches. With our deep cybersecurity expertise, commitment to innovation, and game-changing Next-Generation Security Platform, customers can confidently pursue a digital-first strategy and embark on new technology initiatives, such as cloud and mobility. This kind of thinking and know-how helps customer organizations grow their business and empower employees all while maintaining complete visibility and the control needed to protect their critical control systems and most valued data assets.

11:41 am
NH11:42am

from what I can make out

NH11:42am

rivals are Cisco, Check Point, Sonic Wall and IBM

NH11:42am

But you know more about this space than me

11:42 am
NH11:42am

All I know is that post Qualcomm this is the other tech stock people are following closely

BE11:43am

Hm ............. Interesting. We haven't seen a lot in the way of enterprise software M&A versus, for example, semis.

NH11:43am

I have some grey via Morgan Stanley if people want to know a bit more about the company

11:43 am
BE11:43am

That'd be useful.

NH11:44am

With execution issues behind them, expanded sales capacity against easier comps, and a conservative bar for FY18, we believe it's time to rebuild positions in PANW. We see building traction across Palo Alto Network's broad solution portfolio, increasing the credibility of the Security Platform story and framing a strengthening secular story. This presents an attractive risk/reward for PANW at current levels, and moves us to Overweight on the shares. In our Blue Paper, "Rethinking Security, 04/05/2016" we argued an integrated security platform is needed to drive more efficiency and effectiveness out of cybersecurity investments.

NH11:44am

e believe Palo Alto Network is one of the best positioned vendors to execute on that platform story, as they consolidate network security spend and increasingly end-point security and security analytics – trends which have been supported by recent results and our channel conversations. This attractive platform story has been obfuscated by sales execution issues and more competition in FY17, but we believe we've moved beyond the bottom of the sales challenges, with a new sales coverage model largely in place and

60% of the sales force now fully productive. Our CIO and VAR survey highlights a stable security demand environment with Palo Alto Networks as a share gainer while FY18 guidance for mid single digits product rev growth assumes no meaningful refresh and little continued share gains

11:44 am
NH11:44am

At ~12x EV/CY18 FCF and up only 12% YTD vs. the software avg. +35%, we see room for the multiple (as well as estimates) to move higher through FY18 as investors start giving PANW more credit for durable 20% FCF growth.

NH11:44am

That was from around a month ago

NH11:44am

so a bit out of date

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Interesting. Security sector's been a bit of a laggard this year.

BE11:46am

Morgan Stanley again, from a different note ....

BE11:46am

Large cap security stocks (CHKP, FTNT, SYMC and PANW) trade on average at ~16x NTM FCF, well below the three-year average of 19x, reflecting fears on the durability of the FCF growth profile. Valuation is also attractive on an EV/sales basis, with the average security stock trading at 4.4x NTM sales. This is below the three-year average of 5.1x as well as below the average software M&A multiple of ~5x over the past 18 months. The valuation to fundamental disparity is particularly acute with PANW, trading at 14x CY18 FCF vs. 20%+ FCF growth—a valuation gap which we expect to narrow in CY18 as fundamentals stabilize to improve and investors start giving PANW more credit for durable 20% FCF growth

11:46 am
BE11:46am

So this all looks pretty plausible, though the RAW disclaimer's up there for a good reason.

NH11:47am

indeed

NH11:47am

I have a couple of other stocks to now on the Raw front

11:46 am
NH11:47am

Colgate

NH11:47am

rumours of bid interest

NH11:47am

at $92

11:47 am
NH11:47am

I haven't heard any names

NH11:47am

though I guess 3G will be linked

BE11:47am

Yeah, that's being mentioned a lot by punters. And 3G is the obvious buyer, though not the only one.

11:47 am
NH11:48am

some interest in the November $71.5 calls overnight

NH11:48am

3,500 lots traded

NH11:48am

expire in 10 days

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Hm. We noted here the unusual interest in out-of-the-money calls ahead of the Qualcomm news, of course.

BE11:49am

Nothing illegal about buying on rumour.

NH11:49am

yes, some aggressive buying there

11:49 am
NH11:49am

other than that the only stock that appears to be of some interest is a US cinema chain called Regal Entertainment

undefined
NH11:50am

FJP mentions the Paradise Papers

11:49 am
NH11:50am

I found them a bit disappointing

NH11:50am

but I believe overnight there was some new and interesting

NH11:50am

concerning an old friend of AV

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Likewise. Bono investing in a Lithuanian supermarket wasn't really exciting. Overnight, though, we had a payments processing story.

BE11:50am

http://www.sueddeu...stuetzen-1.3738876

NH11:50am

So i hear

11:51 am
BE11:51am

SZ -- I won't attempt to write the whole name -- wraps together a Paradise Paper story with the non-revelation that online casino services are illegal in Germany

NH11:52am

So far, so Paradise Papers

BE11:52am

Let me do a bit of Google translate ......

11:52 am
BE11:52am

The law leaves little room for interpretation. Anyone who transfers money in connection with illegal gambling in Germany or participates in such payments is illegal. This does not seem to bother many German banks and payment service providers: they regularly violate German gambling laws by processing payments for illegal online casinos.

BE11:52am

Among the banks involved are highly reputable financial institutions. DZ-Bank, Postbank and Hypo-Vereinsbank are accepting funds for illegal gambling services. Other banks, such as Wirecard Bank, maintain accounts for offshore gambling providers through which payments to players are made. According to the Lower Saxony Ministry of the Interior and several bank and criminal law experts, the institutions concerned thereby violate the gambling law, they could also make illegal the aid to illegal gambling and even money laundering.

BE11:53am

So .......... how this works is that the likes of Bwin have temporary permission to run online casinos in Schleswig-Holstein until 2018, while Germany sorts out its legal framework.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

If you don't live in Schleswig-Holstein you can't gamble. In theory. And any bank that handles transactions for players outside Schleswig-Holstein is in violation of German law. In theory.

NH11:53am

I see

BE11:53am

BE11:55am

Firstly the German State Treaty on Gambling has not yet been enacted. Secondly, expert opinion has questioned the compliance of the Treaty with EU law. Therefore, from a legal point of view, the regulation of the German online gambling and online sports-betting market is far from clear.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

More importantly, if German authorities believe EU-licensed online casinos are operating illegally, why has no action been taken against online casinos? We suspect that perhaps the authorities wish to avoid the risk of having to pay compensation for damages resulting from any action against online casinos.

BE11:55am

Operators of sports-betting websites and online casinos advertise on German TV and no action is taken by authorities to prevent such advertising campaigns, which would be possible if such offerings were clearly illegal in the view of the German authorities.

BE11:56am

Online casino operators pay VAT on the revenues generated in Germany. If online casinos were indeed illegal, the State would be officially collecting taxes on illegal services, which seems rather strange.

11:56 am

BE11:56am

We conclude that, contrary to first impressions, the information in the article contains no news regarding Wirecard. In the context of this issue some important points are worthy of note: (1) online casinos operate on European gambling licences; (2) the German State Treaty on Gambling might not be compliant with EU law; (3) the German State Treaty on Gambling has not yet been enacted; (4) the German state collects VAT from online casinos; (5) there is currently no clear legal concept for online gambling in Germany.

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 328.20, up 0.4 (+0.12%), High: 344.20, Low: 316.00, Volume: 12.42m
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Shares have been all over the shop this morning ...

NH12:01pm

The results are a mixed bag

BE12:01pm

... mostly, I guess, because the results are all over the shop. Headlines are decent, strategic plan is ambitious in some parts and prosaic in others.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Cazenove has as good a summary as anyone.

BE12:02pm

H1 18 results are 9% ahead of expectations with the beat stemming from International. Performance in the half has been mixed with Clothing & Home better than expected but Food disappointing on the gross margin. At first glance, we expect no meaningful change to FY 18 consensus forecasts. However, the focus today will be firmly on the group’s strategic update. While the slowing of the Simply Food roll-out might disappoint some, we had become increasingly concerned regarding the magnitude of the incremental space that was being added in the face of cannibalization and competition and believe therefore that this is the right strategy for the long-run health of the business. Similarly, while it is likely to be accompanied by higher near-term exceptional costs, we believe that faster space reduction in C&H is necessary given ongoing market share losses. We do expect the news of a “substantial” cost reduction to be welcomed by investors, although clearly much of this is likely to be reinvested back into the business (for example into “affordability” and in fulfillment capabilities in C&H). We have previously estimated that the group could save c£85m of opex as a result of the plan announced at this time last year: with wider-reaching measures now being taken, our initial assumption would be that a more meaningful saving than this can now be achieved. As was the case with the group’s strategic update at this same time last year, while we believe that initiatives are appropriate for the long-run health of the business, they will take some time to achieve and there are likely to be some heavy exceptional costs (not yet announced). With backing from new Chairman Archie Norman, this strategy is likely to be perceived with more credibility than is often given to retail self-help plans and we think that, overall, the plan will be welcomed by investors from a long-term perspective, but some near-term pain is also likely, particularly ahead of clarity on the magnitude of respective savings and investments.

BE12:05pm

The most striking feature of this update is M&S acknowledging that it has problems in its Food division, with plans to reinvest gross margin and cut back dramatically on the Simply Food store opening program. However there are also important changes here on store closures (which are set to be accelerated), online growth (with management now targeting 30% of sales being generated online) and costs. We suspect that investors will welcome the direction of travel, and applaud the sense of urgency, that this strategy update conveys, though we suspect they would have liked it to be more quantitative.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Having spoken with management, we expect little change to consensus full year Profit Forecasts today for FY 2017/18. There are likely to be a number of moving parts (gross margin guidance has been raised by 50bps for Clothing & Home and lowered by 75bps in Food, whilst profit expectations for the full year in International are likely to increase materially), but we expect them, broadly, to offset each other. According to Bloomberg consensus is currently looking for M&S to deliver Pre Tax Profits of around £580m in FY 2017/18 (giving EPS of 27.5p).

The company has reported H118 results today with PAT of €288.6m a 3% beat on forecast of
€279.8m. This compares to last years reported H117 PAT of €253.4m (+10.5%) but
adjusting for last year’s H117 exceptional of €21.7m (mainly time value of hedge positions)
underlying growth in H118 PAT was up 25% yoy. While a very strong result, we think that
the underlying performance is better than the headlines in that 53% of the H118 capacity
growth of 24% yoy came on new routes rather than increased frequencies, with 4 new
countries, 10 new airports and 42 new airport pairs were served in this period.
